trans-unit.source: Integrating Applications with Azure Active Directory
trans-unit.target: Integrating Applications with Azure Active Directory

trans-unit.source: Enterprise developers and software-as-a-service (SaaS) providers can develop commercial cloud services or line of business applications that can be integrated with Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) to provide secure sign in and authorization for their services.
trans-unit.target: Enterprise developers and software-as-a-service (SaaS) providers can develop commercial cloud services or line of business applications that can be integrated with Azure Active Directory (Azure AD) to provide secure sign in and authorization for their services.

trans-unit.source: To integrate an application or service with Azure AD, a developer must first register the details about their application with Azure AD by using the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: To integrate an application or service with Azure AD, a developer must first register the details about their application with Azure AD by using the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: This article shows you how to add, update, or remove an application in Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: This article shows you how to add, update, or remove an application in Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: You will learn about the different types of applications that can be integrated with Azure AD, how to configure your applications to access other resources such as web APIs, and more.
trans-unit.target: You will learn about the different types of applications that can be integrated with Azure AD, how to configure your applications to access other resources such as web APIs, and more.

trans-unit.source: To more information about app properties, see [Application Objects and Service Principal Objects](active-directory-application-objects.md); to learn the branding guidelines you should use when developing applications with Azure Active Directory, see [Branding Guidelines for Integrated Apps](active-directory-branding-guidelines.md).
trans-unit.target: To more information about app properties, see [Application Objects and Service Principal Objects](active-directory-application-objects.md); to learn the branding guidelines you should use when developing applications with Azure Active Directory, see [Branding Guidelines for Integrated Apps](active-directory-branding-guidelines.md).

trans-unit.source: Adding an Application
trans-unit.target: Adding an Application

trans-unit.source: Any application that wants to use the capabilities of Azure AD must first be registered in a directory.
trans-unit.target: Any application that wants to use the capabilities of Azure AD must first be registered in a directory.

trans-unit.source: This registration process involves giving Azure AD details about your application, such as the URL where it’s located, the URL to send replies after a user is authenticated, the URI that identifies the app, and so on.
trans-unit.target: This registration process involves giving Azure AD details about your application, such as the URL where it’s located, the URL to send replies after a user is authenticated, the URI that identifies the app, and so on.

trans-unit.source: If you’re building a web application that just needs sign-on for users in Azure AD, you can simply follow the instructions below.
trans-unit.target: If you’re building a web application that just needs sign-on for users in Azure AD, you can simply follow the instructions below.

trans-unit.source: If your application needs access to a web API, you’re building a native application that needs to access a web API, or you want to make your application multi-tenant, you’ll need to continue reading in the [Updating an Application](#updating-an-application) section to continue configuring your application.
trans-unit.target: If your application needs access to a web API, you’re building a native application that needs to access a web API, or you want to make your application multi-tenant, you’ll need to continue reading in the [Updating an Application](#updating-an-application) section to continue configuring your application.

trans-unit.source: If you want to make your application available to other organizations, you will also need to enable external access once the application has been added.
trans-unit.target: If you want to make your application available to other organizations, you will also need to enable external access once the application has been added.

trans-unit.source: To register an application in the Azure Management Portal
trans-unit.target: To register an application in the Azure Management Portal

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Active Directory icon on the left menu, and then click on the desired directory.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Active Directory icon on the left menu, and then click on the desired directory.

trans-unit.source: On the top menu, click Applications.
trans-unit.target: On the top menu, click Applications.

trans-unit.source: If no apps have been added to your directory, this page will only show the Add an App link.
trans-unit.target: If no apps have been added to your directory, this page will only show the Add an App link.

trans-unit.source: Click on the link, or alternatively you can click on the Add button on the command bar.
trans-unit.target: Click on the link, or alternatively you can click on the Add button on the command bar.

trans-unit.source: On the What do you want to do page, click on the link to Add an application my organization is developing.
trans-unit.target: On the What do you want to do page, click on the link to Add an application my organization is developing.

trans-unit.source: On the Tell us about your application page, you must specify a name for your application as well as indicate the type of application you are registering with Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: On the Tell us about your application page, you must specify a name for your application as well as indicate the type of application you are registering with Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: You can choose from a web application and/or web API (default) or native client application which represents an application that is installed on a device such as a phone or computer.Once finished, click the arrow icon on the bottom-right corner of the page.
trans-unit.target: You can choose from a web application and/or web API (default) or native client application which represents an application that is installed on a device such as a phone or computer.Once finished, click the arrow icon on the bottom-right corner of the page.

trans-unit.source: On the App properties page, provide the Sign-on URL and App ID URI for your web application (or just the Redirect URI for a native client application), then click the checkbox in the bottom-right hand corner of the page.
trans-unit.target: On the App properties page, provide the Sign-on URL and App ID URI for your web application (or just the Redirect URI for a native client application), then click the checkbox in the bottom-right hand corner of the page.

trans-unit.source: Your application has been added, and you will be taken to the Quick Start page for your application.
trans-unit.target: Your application has been added, and you will be taken to the Quick Start page for your application.

trans-unit.source: Depending on whether your application is a web or native application, you will see different options on how to add additional capabilities to your application.
trans-unit.target: Depending on whether your application is a web or native application, you will see different options on how to add additional capabilities to your application.

trans-unit.source: Once your application has been added, you can begin updating your application to enable users to sign in, access web APIs in other applications, or configure multi-tenant application (which allows other organizations to access your application).
trans-unit.target: Once your application has been added, you can begin updating your application to enable users to sign in, access web APIs in other applications, or configure multi-tenant application (which allows other organizations to access your application).

trans-unit.source: [AZURE.NOTE] By default, the newly created application registration is configured to allow users from your directory to sign in to your application.
trans-unit.target: [AZURE.NOTE] By default, the newly created application registration is configured to allow users from your directory to sign in to your application.

trans-unit.source: Overview of the Consent Framework
trans-unit.target: Overview of the Consent Framework

trans-unit.source: Azure AD’s new consent framework makes it easy to develop web and native applications that need to access web APIs secured by Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: Azure AD’s new consent framework makes it easy to develop web and native applications that need to access web APIs secured by Azure AD.

trans-unit.source: These web APIs include the Graph API, Office 365, and other Microsoft services, in addition to your own web APIs.
trans-unit.target: These web APIs include the Graph API, Office 365, and other Microsoft services, in addition to your own web APIs.

trans-unit.source: The framework is based on a user or an administrator giving consent to an application to be registered in their directory, which may involve accessing directory data.
trans-unit.target: The framework is based on a user or an administrator giving consent to an application to be registered in their directory, which may involve accessing directory data.

trans-unit.source: For example, if a web application needs to call Office 365’s web API to read calendar information about the user, that user will be required to consent to the application.
trans-unit.target: For example, if a web application needs to call Office 365’s web API to read calendar information about the user, that user will be required to consent to the application.

trans-unit.source: After consent is given, the web application will be able to call the Office 365 web API on behalf of the user, and use the calendar information as needed.
trans-unit.target: After consent is given, the web application will be able to call the Office 365 web API on behalf of the user, and use the calendar information as needed.

trans-unit.source: The consent framework is built on OAuth 2.0 and its various flows, such as authorization code grant and client credentials grant, using public or confidential clients.
trans-unit.target: The consent framework is built on OAuth 2.0 and its various flows, such as authorization code grant and client credentials grant, using public or confidential clients.

trans-unit.source: By using OAuth 2.0, Azure AD makes it possible to build many different types of client applications, such as on a phone, tablet, server, or a web application, and gain access to the required resources.
trans-unit.target: By using OAuth 2.0, Azure AD makes it possible to build many different types of client applications, such as on a phone, tablet, server, or a web application, and gain access to the required resources.

trans-unit.source: For more detailed information about the consent framework, see [OAuth 2.0 in Azure AD](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn645545.aspx), [Authentication Scenarios for Azure AD](active-directory-authentication-scenarios.md), and Office 365’s topic [Authentication and Authorization using Common Consent Framework](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/office/dn605895(v=office.15).aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more detailed information about the consent framework, see [OAuth 2.0 in Azure AD](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn645545.aspx), [Authentication Scenarios for Azure AD](active-directory-authentication-scenarios.md), and Office 365’s topic [Authentication and Authorization using Common Consent Framework](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/office/dn605895(v=office.15).aspx).

trans-unit.source: If the application has not already acquired an access or refresh token, the application needs to go to Azure AD’s authorization endpoint to obtain an authorization code that can be used to acquire a new access and refresh token.
trans-unit.target: If the application has not already acquired an access or refresh token, the application needs to go to Azure AD’s authorization endpoint to obtain an authorization code that can be used to acquire a new access and refresh token.

trans-unit.source: If the user is not already authenticated, they’ll be asked to sign in to Azure AD.
trans-unit.target: If the user is not already authenticated, they’ll be asked to sign in to Azure AD.

trans-unit.target: After the user has signed in, Azure AD will determine if the user needs to be shown a consent page.

trans-unit.source: This determination is based on whether the user (or their organization’s administrator) has already granted the application consent.
trans-unit.target: This determination is based on whether the user (or their organization’s administrator) has already granted the application consent.

trans-unit.target: If consent has not already been granted, Azure AD will prompt the user for consent and will display the required permissions it needs to function.

trans-unit.target: The set of permissions that is displayed in the consent dialog are the same as what was selected in the Permissions to other applications control in the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Accessing Web APIs in Other Applications
trans-unit.target: Accessing Web APIs in Other Applications

trans-unit.source: Using the consent framework described above, you can configure your application to require permissions to access data exposed by web APIs in your directory.
trans-unit.target: Using the consent framework described above, you can configure your application to require permissions to access data exposed by web APIs in your directory.

trans-unit.source: By default, all applications can choose permissions from Azure Active Directory (Graph API) and Azure Service Management API, with the Azure AD “Enable sign on and read user’s profile” permission already selected by default.
trans-unit.target: By default, all applications can choose permissions from Azure Active Directory (Graph API) and Azure Service Management API, with the Azure AD “Enable sign on and read user’s profile” permission already selected by default.

trans-unit.source: If your directory also has a subscription to Office 365, then web APIs and permissions for SharePoint and Exchange Online will also be available for selection.
trans-unit.target: If your directory also has a subscription to Office 365, then web APIs and permissions for SharePoint and Exchange Online will also be available for selection.

trans-unit.source: You can select from two types of permissions in the drop-down menus next to the desired web API:
trans-unit.target: You can select from two types of permissions in the drop-down menus next to the desired web API:

trans-unit.source: Application Permissions: Your application needs to access the web API directly as itself (no user context).
trans-unit.target: Application Permissions: Your application needs to access the web API directly as itself (no user context).

trans-unit.source: This type of permission requires administrator consent and is also not available for native client applications.
trans-unit.target: This type of permission requires administrator consent and is also not available for native client applications.

trans-unit.source: Delegation Permissions: Your application needs to access the web API as the signed-in user, but with access limited by the selected permission.
trans-unit.target: Delegation Permissions: Your application needs to access the web API as the signed-in user, but with access limited by the selected permission.

trans-unit.source: This type of permission can be granted by a user unless the permission is configured as requiring administrator consent.
trans-unit.target: This type of permission can be granted by a user unless the permission is configured as requiring administrator consent.

trans-unit.source: Configuring Multi-Tenant Applications
trans-unit.target: Configuring Multi-Tenant Applications

trans-unit.source: When adding an application to Azure AD, you may want your application to be accessed only by users in your organization.
trans-unit.target: When adding an application to Azure AD, you may want your application to be accessed only by users in your organization.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, you may want your application to be accessed by users in external organizations.
trans-unit.target: Alternatively, you may want your application to be accessed by users in external organizations.

trans-unit.source: These two application types are called single tenant and multi-tenant applications.
trans-unit.target: These two application types are called single tenant and multi-tenant applications.

trans-unit.source: You can modify the configuration of a single tenant application to make it a multi-tenant application, which this section discusses below.
trans-unit.target: You can modify the configuration of a single tenant application to make it a multi-tenant application, which this section discusses below.

trans-unit.source: It’s important to note the differences between a single tenant and multi-tenant application.
trans-unit.target: It’s important to note the differences between a single tenant and multi-tenant application.

trans-unit.source: A single tenant application is intended for use in one organization.
trans-unit.target: A single tenant application is intended for use in one organization.

trans-unit.source: They are typically a line-of-business (LoB) application written by an enterprise developer.
trans-unit.target: They are typically a line-of-business (LoB) application written by an enterprise developer.

trans-unit.source: A single tenant application only needs to be accessed by users in one directory, and as a result, it only needs to be provisioned in one directory.
trans-unit.target: A single tenant application only needs to be accessed by users in one directory, and as a result, it only needs to be provisioned in one directory.

trans-unit.source: A multi-tenant application intended for use in many organizations.
trans-unit.target: A multi-tenant application intended for use in many organizations.

trans-unit.source: They are typically a software-as-a-service (SaaS) application written by an independent software vendor (ISV).
trans-unit.target: They are typically a software-as-a-service (SaaS) application written by an independent software vendor (ISV).

trans-unit.source: Multi-tenant applications need to be provisioned in each directory where they will be used, which requires user or administrator consent to register them.
trans-unit.target: Multi-tenant applications need to be provisioned in each directory where they will be used, which requires user or administrator consent to register them.

trans-unit.source: Enabling OAuth 2.0 Implicit Grant for Single Page Applications
trans-unit.target: Enabling OAuth 2.0 Implicit Grant for Single Page Applications

trans-unit.source: Single Page Application’s (SPAs) are typically structured with a JavaScript-heavy front end that runs in the browser, which calls the application’s web API back end to perform its business logic.
trans-unit.target: Single Page Application’s (SPAs) are typically structured with a JavaScript-heavy front end that runs in the browser, which calls the application’s web API back end to perform its business logic.

trans-unit.source: For SPAs hosted in Azure AD, you use OAuth 2.0 Implicit Grant to authenticate the user with Azure AD and obtain a token that you can use to secure calls from the application's JavaScript client to its back end web API.
trans-unit.target: For SPAs hosted in Azure AD, you use OAuth 2.0 Implicit Grant to authenticate the user with Azure AD and obtain a token that you can use to secure calls from the application's JavaScript client to its back end web API.

trans-unit.source: After the user has granted consent, this same authentication protocol can be used to obtain tokens to secure calls between the client and other web API resources configured for the application.
trans-unit.target: After the user has granted consent, this same authentication protocol can be used to obtain tokens to secure calls between the client and other web API resources configured for the application.

trans-unit.source: By default, OAuth 2.0 Implicit Grant is disabled for applications.
trans-unit.target: By default, OAuth 2.0 Implicit Grant is disabled for applications.

trans-unit.source: You can enable OAuth 2.0 Implicit Grant for your application by setting the `oauth2AllowImplicitFlow`”` value in its application manifest, which is a JSON file that represents your application's identity configuration.
trans-unit.target: You can enable OAuth 2.0 Implicit Grant for your application by setting the `oauth2AllowImplicitFlow`”` value in its application manifest, which is a JSON file that represents your application's identity configuration.

trans-unit.target: To enable OAuth 2.0 Implicit Grant

trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.target: Click on the **Active Directory** icon on the left menu, then click on the desired directory.

trans-unit.target: On the top menu, click **Applications**, and then click the application you want to configure.

trans-unit.target: The Quick Start page will appear with single sign-on and other configuration information.

trans-unit.target: Click on the **Manage manifest** button in the command bar, and select **Download manifest**.

trans-unit.source: Open the JSON application manifest file and set the “oauth2AllowImplicitFlow” value to “true”.
trans-unit.target: Open the JSON application manifest file and set the “oauth2AllowImplicitFlow” value to “true”.

trans-unit.source: By default, it is “false”.
trans-unit.target: By default, it is “false”.

trans-unit.source: See [Using the Graph API to Query Azure AD](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn151791.aspx) for an example of where this update should happen.
trans-unit.target: See [Using the Graph API to Query Azure AD](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/azure/dn151791.aspx) for an example of where this update should happen.

trans-unit.source: You should now roll this change out across your production environment – verifying it first on one service node, before rolling it out across the rest.
trans-unit.target: You should now roll this change out across your production environment – verifying it first on one service node, before rolling it out across the rest.

trans-unit.source: Once the update is complete across your production deployment, you are free to come back to the Azure Management Portal and remove the old key.
trans-unit.target: Once the update is complete across your production deployment, you are free to come back to the Azure Management Portal and remove the old key.

trans-unit.source: Changing App Properties After Enabling Access (Legacy)
trans-unit.target: Changing App Properties After Enabling Access (Legacy)

trans-unit.source: Once you enable access for external users to your app, you may still continue to make changes to your app’s properties in the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Once you enable access for external users to your app, you may still continue to make changes to your app’s properties in the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: However, customers who have already granted access to your app before you made app changes will not see those changes reflected when viewing details about your app in the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: However, customers who have already granted access to your app before you made app changes will not see those changes reflected when viewing details about your app in the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Once the app is made available to customers, you need to be very careful when making certain changes.
trans-unit.target: Once the app is made available to customers, you need to be very careful when making certain changes.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you update the App ID URI, then your existing customers who granted access before this change will be unable to log in to your app using their company or school accounts.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you update the App ID URI, then your existing customers who granted access before this change will be unable to log in to your app using their company or school accounts.

trans-unit.source: If you make a change to the RequestedPermissions to request a greater access level, existing customers using app functionality that now leverages new API calls using this increased access level may get an access denied response from the Graph API.
trans-unit.target: If you make a change to the RequestedPermissions to request a greater access level, existing customers using app functionality that now leverages new API calls using this increased access level may get an access denied response from the Graph API.

trans-unit.source: Your app should handle these cases and ask the customer to grant access to your app with the request for an increased access level.
trans-unit.target: Your app should handle these cases and ask the customer to grant access to your app with the request for an increased access level.

trans-unit.source: Removing an Application
trans-unit.target: Removing an Application

trans-unit.source: This section describes how to remove an application from your directory for both single tenant and multi-tenant applications.
trans-unit.target: This section describes how to remove an application from your directory for both single tenant and multi-tenant applications.

trans-unit.source: To remove a single tenant application from your directory
trans-unit.target: To remove a single tenant application from your directory

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Active Directory icon on the left menu, and then click on the desired directory.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Active Directory icon on the left menu, and then click on the desired directory.

trans-unit.source: On the top menu, click Applications, and then click the application you want to configure.
trans-unit.target: On the top menu, click Applications, and then click the application you want to configure.

trans-unit.source: The Quick Start page will appear with single sign-on and other configuration information.
trans-unit.target: The Quick Start page will appear with single sign-on and other configuration information.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Delete button in the command bar.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Delete button in the command bar.

trans-unit.source: Click Yes in the confirmation message.
trans-unit.target: Click Yes in the confirmation message.

trans-unit.source: To remove a multi-tenant application from your directory
trans-unit.target: To remove a multi-tenant application from your directory

trans-unit.source: Sign in to the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: Sign in to the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Active Directory icon on the left menu, and then click on the desired directory.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Active Directory icon on the left menu, and then click on the desired directory.

trans-unit.source: On the top menu, click Applications, and then click the application you want to configure.
trans-unit.target: On the top menu, click Applications, and then click the application you want to configure.

trans-unit.source: The Quick Start page will appear with single sign-on and other configuration information.
trans-unit.target: The Quick Start page will appear with single sign-on and other configuration information.

trans-unit.source: On the Application is multi-tenant section, click No.
trans-unit.target: On the Application is multi-tenant section, click No.

trans-unit.source: This converts your application to be single tenant, but the application will still remain in an organization who has already consented to it.
trans-unit.target: This converts your application to be single tenant, but the application will still remain in an organization who has already consented to it.

trans-unit.source: Click on the Delete button in the command bar.
trans-unit.target: Click on the Delete button in the command bar.

trans-unit.source: Click Yes in the confirmation message.
trans-unit.target: Click Yes in the confirmation message.

trans-unit.source: In order for a company administrator to remove an app’s access to their directory (after having granted consent), the company administrator must have an Azure subscription to remove access through the Azure Management Portal.
trans-unit.target: In order for a company administrator to remove an app’s access to their directory (after having granted consent), the company administrator must have an Azure subscription to remove access through the Azure Management Portal.

trans-unit.source: Alternatively, the company administrator can use the [Azure AD PowerShell Cmdlets](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkId=294151) to remove access.
